newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS - Bund volatility slides post-payrolls data.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Bund volatility slides post-payrolls data.

text.p: Bund volatility took a tumble after the release on key U.S. employment data on Friday, heading for the five percent level, traders said.
Volatility has been supported by the figures all week, as traders were unwilling to push it down when faced with a number which could swing the market violently.
Stripped of that support, volatility started to slide.

"April is at 5.46-5.85 percent. That's down about a point -- it was 6.5 percent this morning. May would be about 5.6-5.7 percent and June 5.5-5.6 percent -- they're both down about half a point," said a trader at a British brokerage here.
February non-farm payrolls rose 339,000, compared with a forecast of 230,000. January was revised down to a rise of 247,000 from 271,000.
June Bund futures were up eight basis points at 101.75 by 1500 GMT.
Traders said volume was light ahead of the number, and had not been overwhelming afterwards because of the weekend.
A salesman at a European bank said activity was strongest in the front month, where the 101.00 strike puts and the 102.00 strike calls were the most active.
"But there's still no clear direction, though it should go off a little further," he said. "It could be a chance to buy volatility."
The British brokerage trader also said volume was unimpressive after the data, as the market moved in a rather directionless way.
The European bank salesman said he expected volatility to gravitate towards the five percent level during the coming week, although it would be difficult to break below there.
